commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Sign out?  (4)
2. Alternatively ... !!!  (2)(4)
3. They don't give you the full picture  (5)(8)
4. Ones no longer in office?  (6)(7)
5. Do a little too well?  (4)


EXIT
OR ELSE
MOVIE TRAILERS
REMOTE WORKERS
CHAR

Today was not my day. 9 minute solve. 7 minutes to fill plus two minutes to resolve. Had a Natick with DRAT/DEVO, misspelled EASaL (didn't know ADLER).

So I was in ANTIGUA 12 years ago this weekend. I remember because it was during the 2014 Winter Olympics and over a holiday weekend, so had to be Presidents Day. I distinctly remember thinking of a specific line from the Jamaica Kincaid book. It was the first time I ever heard the word quaint (when we read it in elementary school). I fully understood what she meant and why she said it once I got there.

As for the MIT Mystery HUNT, when I went to MathCamp (which is exactly what it sounds like), they had a similar puzzle weekend based on the MIT version. A lot of the counselors were MIT grad/doc students. Our team won. We stayed all night, solving the final puzzle around 4 AM. The prize was getting to design the hunt next year. I was very disappointed that the winning team the next year solved all of our puzzles by midnight

Our constructor writes:
"Thrilled to have a constructor byline on a daily crossword again ‚Äî my first since 2016!"

Ian,
I'm not surprised you were on hiatus after that 2016 puzzle. No more Thursdays for you! Delighted you're on staff now, and making other puzzles. Hope you'll be permitted to treat us to a Sunday. I hope the new solvers will know today's proper nouns from the clues or find them gently crossed.
Now we need to check the ID of today's guest columnist.

One and done. No lookups. Wheee...

Just in time to watch my favorite TV show: America's Funniest Videos. Tonight: watching people cut down trees!!!

Nice clues that made me think a little for a Monday. Surprised I remembered a certain newspaper comic strip that I haven't thought about in years. I managed to beat my Monday average by 50 whole seconds. Also, today I finished up every NYT Crossword since January 1st, 2020 through the present and am that much closer to doing the full online archives. Cheers all & happy solving!

Nice to have a Monday puzzle that's more than just filling in the blanks.  Not too difficult for newcomers and not too boring for old timers, a difficult balance to maintain.    

Thank you, Ian, some cool IDeas.
Pretty difficult for a Monday and a few answers that felt like a stretch. Frustrating beginning to the week for sure.

Thanks for the archive tip! And I do enjoy Pips. 
Nice intro to a fun puzzle.

Doula and raw bar are now in my vocabulary.

A raw bar in the Ozarks is a nekkid grizzly.

Y'all.

Oddly this was a Monday I appreciated the fill and the clues more than the theme. Nothing against it, I suppose, just seemed a little half baked to use Ian‚Äôs original IDiom. And while my Superego was proud of solving it and my Ego thought it was well balanced my ID didn‚Äôt get much of a kick out of it. But it was a crunchier Monday than usual and for once I had to jump around a bit, and I appreciated the care and  thought behind the clues more than the usual Monday.
If they waited a couple of weeks, we could have had the ƒ™Ds of March.

Solid Monday puzzle.

13A was easy for me, as I spent a month in LILLE some 10 years ago, or so. The city is friendly and fun to explore, and there are tons of day trips one can do by train, elsewhere in France or in Belgium.

One kind of tourism in that region is visiting WWI battle sites of the Western Front. There are some very famous ones such as Ypres and La Somme, but as Canadians we of course went to Vimy Ridge, taking a train from Lille to Arras. That day is still with me. The first part of the tour is given by Canadian college students in park ranger uniforms. They show you the trenches and tunnels, and recount how the battle played out, emphasizing the Canadian know-how, discipline and grit. It's incredible to hear this story standing where it all happened. But the most moving part of the visit is when you walk up to the towering stone memorial on the ridge, which remembers some 60,000 Canadian soldiers killed during the Great War. That war to end all wars.

I‚ÄôD say this was a nice, chewy Monday. I pulled THE WIZARD OF ID somewhere out of the deep recesses of my mind. IDaho is one of three states I have left to visit out of 50. I‚Äôm hoping to check it off of my bucket list this year. ü§ûüèº Has anyone visited all 50 states?

Thanks for kicking off the week, Ian.

Misdirected myself with rate for WAGE. Spent too much time on that alone.  Oops. Should have been smooth sailing but my rutter got stuck in Antigua and there I also lost my dinghy. 

Your toughie redux for the day is 6/16/2022. A Thursday with a puzzle inside the puzzle.  Just roll with it.
34a is, for the record, inaccurate. That's not who that was.

I looked up Ian‚Äôs 2016 puzzle. I loved it! An extra challenge for constructor and solver alike. It helped me that I knew 1A straight away, being my favorite musical artist, so I caught onto the trick pretty early. 

Pips is currently my fav puzzle. Can‚Äôt wait until we get the archive of all the puzzles the Canadians got to test out for us :-)

I lived in Lille for a year and had visited several times besides, so this was a sweet little surprise. The city stays under the radar for many tourists but I always recommend it to travelers‚Äîit‚Äôs easy to get to and around, and makes a great pit stop on a Paris to Amsterdam route!

"Should I measure this in pounds or kilograms?"
"Either weigh."

(I had other puns, but they scale in comparison.)

I reread the Wordplay column and comments for Ian's 2016 puzzle. I believe 344 comments was record back then! The puzzle: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2016/09/15 The column: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/15/crosswords/trapped.html
Prince Valiant has the same number of letters as THE WIZARD OF ID.
Arranging my DOULA led to a faster delivery today. ID say I really enjoyed that one but how could I not sitting by a pool in Bali where the puzzles arrive 3 hours earlier!
Unfortunately, Mr. Livengood does not appear to know what the word in 15 Across means‚Ä¶

Not much to say about the puzzle as such - it was a typical Monday, with a theme that didn't grab me.

I actually remembered BOISE, ID from when my wife and I crossed its outskirts on our way from Oregon to Wyoming. The place itself didn't seem memorable, but we were confused as to how to pronounce it - it looked French-ish, so we interpreted it to sound like the -boise bit of the Loire town of Amboise. We checked, and were surprised to realize our mistake.

It's so sad that humans killed all DODO BIRDs and then to add insult to injury they made them the symbol of s7up!d!7y... We're so smart and empathetic, aren't we?

I still remember how the word ALLEY confused me when I first learned it several decades ago. You see, in Polish we have the word "aleja", which sounds much alike your ALLEY, and the two words also share their etymology - both derive from the French "aller", "to walk". However, in Polish "aleja" means... an avenue: a long, tree-lined, usually wide street or road, exactly what any ALLEY is not. The grandest, most elegant streets of our cities are called "Aleje".
Also, the word for 45 Across is also incorrect, as any Encyclopedia Brown fan will be able to attest.
It was impressive that every ID was a stand-alone word, not merely part of a longer word. I love it when someone notices a particularity in words and can turn that into a symmetrical puzzle!

Thank you for your helping tips on crosswords. I‚Äôm still relatively new to crosswords so I really appreciate the tips. 
Especially for 36-Across!

PEDIGREE is an odd word and is thought to derive from the French ‚Äúp√© de grue‚Äù, meaning ‚Äúfoot of crane‚Äù, apparently because the shape of that bird‚Äôs foot resembled the way the family line was depicted on a heraldic family tree.
I must have seen DOULA written down before but I still had to flyspeck and realise something was wrong when I couldn't work out what a HoNT was.
this was a really good Monday witty and wise thanks Ian!

The Mini had CONVO for "chat" and POOFY for "Like a voluminous winter jacket." Modern English is leaving me behind. I may have to take an ESL course even though English was my first language too.

The only similar surprise in the main puzzle was SHE-hulk, SHE-huh?
TIL that PRINCEVALIANT and THEWIZARDOFID have the same number of letters. Ask me how I know.
Surprisingly tricky for a Monday. Delayed me for longer than expected. Enjoyably so.

Were the puzzles of the past harder or is it just that the cultural references are dated? Some oldies have trivia that have not stood the test of time as I suspect most rappers of today‚Äôs puzzle won‚Äôt. The oldies do offer more resistance. 

Monday 16/2/97 is a nice puzzle. For a nonUSAian a tad more challenging than a normal Monday these days but quite clever. 

I‚Äôm guessing some town in Texas will rename itself Thump.

Pretty tricky today, more than usual. The BOISE/HUNT/RAW BAR combination was the toughest for me. 
Still enjoyable .
@Tom Wright-Piersanti Nice job on the Wordplay column. Your way of offering encouragement and practical tips feels right at home on a Monday. Tonally, as if you'd always been here. Nailed it.
A question mark at the end of a clue doesn't necessarily indicate a pun. It just means there's some kind of wordplay involved.

Oh, excellent Monday cluing, with more-than-usual answers featuring The Beat, where just for a moment I had to think about the clue before putting the answer down.  Without The Beat, it‚Äôs an immediate no-think slap-down, and a puzzle with too many slap-downs is a throwaway, forgettable. But with sufficient mind-engaging entries, this puzzle kept my interest throughout.

As @dutchiris beautifully said earlier, not too difficult for newcomers, and not too boring for old timers.

I liked seeing THE WIZARD OF ID, which I haven‚Äôt thought about in ages, and read a bit about it after solving because I wondered why the Kingdom of Id was named for Freud‚Äôs ‚Äúid‚Äù. Turns out It was ruled by a short, tyrannical and petty king who acts on his impulses, that is, he‚Äôs id-based.  That strip is in its 62nd year, BTW.

Welcome back, Ian, after a decade‚Äôs absence, and congratulations on your 56th NYT puzzle.  May this be the start of a new run.  Thank you for a most lovely Monday puzzle!
Is it not a stretch to say LILLE is NNE of Paris? This one took me ages, not least because my Google Maps shows it as Rijssel.

Frammin‚Äô at the Jim-Jam, Frippin‚Äô in the Krotz!


(I mean that in the sense of definition #3 at Websters.
You can look it up for yourselves :)
Today's mini caused me to fail the speed benchmark, but it was fun anyway.
I have a quibble with the answer ‚Äúvamp‚Äù for 15 across, (‚ÄúImprovise in jazz‚Äù). Vamping is repeating a riff of pattern, and is the opposite of improvisation.

It's Monday, so I come with low expectations, but I think this puzzle needs a (better) revealer.

I agree with the editors that "Half-baked IDea" doesn't quite work because of the "baked".
But what about the more straightforward "Half of an IDea"?
I feel certain I've heard someone say, "You've got 'half of an IDea' there.  Come back when you finish it."

What do you think?

This theme isn't landing for me. The four IDs all go the same way, not either way. Meh.

Okay, I'll go read the column and comments, see what I'm missing.

Otherwise, good fill for a Monday. Not tough, but fresh.
And brownie points for DEVO.

I didn't notice 54A as a revealer. I thought POLLS was the loosely-related revealer, especially given it's placement in the grid. And if that were the case, surely DEM was not coincidental. From THE WIZARD OF oz, here's the scarecrow noting that "Of course, people do go both ways." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yejtZgzB5Ik

The "reveal" for me was that there was a SHE-Hulk movie made in 2022.  I'D wished I'D have known that.  

And, it's pronounced EYE-GOR!

Joking aside, nice puzzle.  Thanks.

Nice Monday puzzle. The usual workout and... 54a was almost the last thing I filled in, so that was a nice 'aha' moment when I finally caught on to the theme. And then, did a search and learned that... "Answers that begin with ID?" 358 different ones that have appeared in puzzles. and... "Answers that end with ID?" 689 different ones. And my puzzle find: a Friday from December 12, 1975 by Dennis Listort. Three 15 letter answers in that one. WHATDIDDELWARE IDONTKNOWALASKA WHENDIDMARYLAND Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/12/1975&g=35&d=A I'm done. ...

I was sure the revealer would be LET ME SEE SOME ID.  I wasn't expecting this revealer, and I don;t think it works.  To fit ID GO EITHER WAY, the IDs would have to read as both ID and DI in different theme answers.  The correct revealer for what we have here would be ID GO ON EITHER SIDE.

Yes, I know puzzles needn't be taken too literally.  But this one just doesn't work for me.  And, after all, the constructor could have done the ID/DI thing.

That said, it was a perfectly pleasant puzzle to work on.

One of those kinds of puzzles:  O. T. S.  (As in "Over Too Soon.")

Do some people eat clams RAW?  Oysters, yes, but clams?  EWW
I love clams with bacon, parsley, oniion, and garlic on bucatini...    I had a nice little parsley bed going before the Winter turned vicious.  (Italian parsley, I should clarify.)

SEN before DEM.
Never could get into THE WIZARD OF ID when we were taking a paper...  Actually, after POGO and PEANUTS, it was all downhill.  

The Springerle were a hit--even the ones that were less-than-perfect.  Maybe I won't hang up the cookie molds after all.....

I struggled a bit with 27D. The answer should have been a 9-square containing "of all." Alternatively, the clue could have read "____ of all." It's poor cluing and clearly the editors paid no attention to last week's analogous "poodly" debate.
Be better, young creators.


(No harm was intended)

Did not like this one at all. The repetition of the theme letters without a unifying clue is poor design to me. Some of the clues and answers are also really strange and weirdly hit the extremes of "tries to use new-age language" and "clearly grew up a long time ago" rather than just sticking with one or the other (examples include BADASS and GOTH, contrasted with DODOBIRD). One of my least favorite Mondays in a while.

Thank you, Ian, for what felt like a crunchier than usual Monday -- I enjoyed it! Tom, thank you for your insightful commentary into your journey in xword solving. The archives certainly help with cognitive conditioning!

Happy Monday, everyone!
I hate to call a construction sloppy, but there were too many IDs floating around, unrelated to the theme. OVID and RAID for example. Monsters from the ID, perhaps?

Thanks for the pleasant Monday Ian!

I‚Äôm really digging Pips as the new logic game on the block; it‚Äôs the game I most look forward to after the crossword. The simplicity of form and the novelty of reasoning help exercise this creaky brain of mine. Thanks for bringing it to us!

Yes, LILLE is lovely. I‚Äôve been several times for a weekend of cuisine √† la Francais, it being just a hop and a skip under the Channel on Eurostar. Definitely worth a visit.

The puzzle; never one to decry the skill of constructors, after all, it‚Äôs completely beyond my ability, but this one was a bit MEH for me. Nothing wrong with it, but felt a tad pedestrian.

I do love the weekly news quiz though.
tough monday off the bat - great puzzle that required some effort!
I enjoyed this one.  A fun, easy Monday solve, but just a little bit harder on the clues that required an ounce or two more of brain power. Thank you, creator.

This one leaned a but Tuesdayish to me, but I enjoyed all the interesting answers like THE WIZARD OF ID (19A) RAW BAR (47A), and DODO BIRD (8D). 

After my dad retired, he enjoyed making wooden dodo bird garden ornaments. The body was attached to the stake in the ground, and head was attached by a metal strap. Their heads would bob up and down in the wind. Those were my favorites. üòä

This was fun to solve, but the theme didn't quite cohere. It wanted a revealer, in my opinion.

Still, I had fun! BEAR HUG, DOULA, VAMP, lots of lively fill. I'm now trying to imagine what a GOTH BRO might look like. Robert Smith, but swole and peddling protein powder?
A pleasant, gentle start to the week. Thanks Ian.

At least two clues rang hollow to my ear: "Corrosion signs" for RUSTS, and "Glitterati" for IN CROWDS.

In both cases the plural answer screams "Huh?!?" to me.

Also, has anyone really ever said I'D GO EITHER WAY ?
Hit a 500 day streak with this one!

This puzzle makes me worry that there‚Äôs some kind of grift going on ‚Ä¶ we see puzzles by game staff so often, (which IMO shouldn‚Äôt be allowed) and this absolute snooze of a puzzle with a barely coherent theme troubles me when I see my constructor friends‚Äô really excellent, clever and unique puzzles get constantly rejected. If a staff member has a puzzle published, it should set the bar for the rest of the constructors out there and not be so 46D, and hopefully they are not also paid to maintain integrity to it.

Today‚Äôs poem

metamorphoses

a/ through the city
heavy through the night
d/ the buildings bunch and droop
as the instant thickens and
a/ the crowds go in
Sad to see "raw bar" in a NY Times crossword puzzle. I now have to cede to its reality.

Among other tings, it bothered me that fill contained both EMO and GOTH, both clued to music/lifestyle genres, and not, say [Funny man Phillips] or [Speaker of an extinct East Germanic language]. Now aficionados will argue that goth and emo are completely different beasts, but the presence of so many webpages trying to explain the difference, implies that there is more similarity than not. Label jars, not genres. Here's Gerard Way, of My Chemical Romance, wearing heavy eyeliner to the confessional: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCCyoocDxBA&list=RDUCCyoocDxBA&start_radio=1
Has anyone ever used ‚Äúfiddlesticks‚Äù to mean something along the lines of ‚Äúdarn‚Äù? I always assumed it to mean ‚Äúnonsense‚Äù, which is the meaning that Webster‚Äôs provides.

Finally got to the puzzle. My brain is half fried at this time of day, but the "theme" makes little sense to me. I even read the column in the hope of learning that I missed something, but ... no luck.

Maybe when I read the comments I'll be illuminated, but right now I'm wondering how this even got published. ID can refer to the id, to Idaho, to identification and, with an apostrophe, can mean "I would". That's the "theme"? Please tell me there's something more.

**SPOILERS** proceed with caution:
________________________________

A bit peeved by the identity of some of these clues.

1) VAMP is not, itself, improvisation. It‚Äôs supposed to be the consistent piece that allows improvising to happen around it.

2) I had to Google search ‚Äúglitterati‚Äù and literally the top result is the Word Tips page for today‚Äôs crossword using it as a clue. This clue word does not seem like a rather common or popular word, so it just feels very out of place to me for a Monday puzzle.

Does anybody else remember The IN CROWD?... https://youtu.be/I1oxpADF5Bs?si=vhbmeQ4tBnxFY3QW And I see that it's the NYT IN CROWD that has graced us both with the column and the puzzle today. Thank you, gents! @Barry Ancona was kind, as usual, to link us to the mentioned 2016 puzzle by Mr. Livengood. I wasn't a crossworder yet back then, but boy, that would have been most probably way above my paygrade. It seems many in the commentariat were unable to figure it out and posted words of anger not used in this forum, enough to have Deb Amlen step in to remind all of the expected civility. I really don't blame Mr. Livengood for taking ten years to return *and* keep it Monday-straightforward this time around. Welcome back, Mr. Livengood, and thank you for reminding me of The Wizard of Id! (right up there with Asterix for me!)

I tried to post a comment (two, actually...) this morning -- several hours ago -- but I guess this poor little clam is no longer allowed to say "Gaaaaah! " When an answer like RAW BAR shows upon the puzzle...
Apologies in advance... IDaho? No! You da ho! (I'm originally from Idaho so I can get away with it.)
Is today Thursday? Worst Monday time in years. What the heck is a "raw bar?"
Well done, Mr. Livengood!  And I went to the September 15, 2016 puzzle of yours that was mentioned and I was astounded. It is in a class by itself. Brilliant!
Holy moly! This might be the toughest Monday crossword I‚Äôve seen in a hot minute.

haven't needed help on a monday in probably years. well. i guess it's nice that we're increasing the difficulty since monday has always been sort of a fluff day for me. i do it to do it, but it's never challenging or fun. i dID like the theme despite rampant opposition from my fellow solvers. i dIDn't enjoy glitterati (genuinely never heard that in my life, crossed with RAWBAR--another new one for me--and my SKIM - SCAN misfill didn't help) 

Overall, there were  a lot of hard ones. IGOR, UNIX, OVID, THE WIZARD OF ID, ADLER, and EARP were all really strange fills for a Monday. I'm not complaining about them getting tougher, but if that's the strategy you'd think they would mention it. :)
These clues are terrible. Worst Monday crossword I‚Äôve ever tried to play.

The comments section never fails to entertain. It's odd. So many people compared this puzzle to a Thursday puzzle. For me, it was a fairly straight forward Monday puzzle, and I am a person who struggles to fill in anything past Wednesday.

In any event, bravo. Thank you for this heady diversion on an otherwise fairly dreary day. Thank you for your efforts. I am truly grateful.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Dating qualifier]  (5)
[Really fancy?]  (5)


CIRCA
COVET

@Steven M. I agree. While I enjoyed it and worked my way through, my pace was slower than my usual Mondays. It definitely felt more like a Tuesday to me and I was tempted to check the calendar to make sure I hadn't slept through Monday!

@Steven M.

I was in ANTIGUA just over a year later, in March 2015. I went with my mother and stayed in the same hotel in Falmouth Harbor where she had visited just before I was born (many decades prior!). She said virtually nothing had changed in the area; we loved our vacation there!
@Lige good one!

@SP

Do you expect to get a kick out of a Monday though?

@Andrzej

I sometimes get a kick out of the theme but not the rest of the puzzle. Today it was the other way around

@Lewis 
Beware . . . we'll just have to wait to see what that day brings.üòâ
@Lewis they absolutely should have!
@Esmerelda: do I remember right that you are also a DOULA?

@Cat Lady Margaret

Yes! Glad to see that answer show up as well!

@Esmerelda Thank you for this. I hadn't heard the story of Vimy Ridge. We in the US must remember that the population of Canada in 1916 was only eight million. Here is a link to the Wikipedia article on the commander of the Canadian Corps at Vimy Ridge. He subsequently became Governor-General of Canada. Hockey fans may recognize the name. His wife established the Lady Byng Trophy. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julian_Byng,_1st_Viscount_Byng_of_Vimy

userLocation: Spring training again. Ahh, at last! ‚öæÔ∏è
commentBody:
@Esmerelda
Thank you for this note on Canada's role in WWI.

Remembrance Day (as we anglophones know it) was strictly observed at our parochial school because we understood deep in our bones that many of us would have lost family or never existed were it not for the insane bravery of Canadian forces in both World Wars. We memorized 'In Flanders Field'. We wore poppies. We were proud and sad.

Ypres, Vimy Ridge, Passchaendele, the terrible battles on earth oozing blood are still commonly referred to as 'Canada's coming of age.'

commentBody:
@Madtown Greg
Thanks for the gen on the Payton award. But Lady Byng rewarded gentlemanly play -- i.e., on the field of play, not beyond the game. To my mind, a much tougher achievement.

@Jacqui J
When in Idaho, don‚Äôt miss Craters of the Moon National Monument. Fascinating and not well known. Also, our visit to Alaska last year, including three national parks, made 50 states for hubby. A happy milestone.
@A&W that‚Äôs awesome. Alaska is beautiful and well worth the trip.
@A&W thank you for the recommendation when we visit Idaho ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Jacqui J
Only one I haven't visited is Oregon, much to my dismay. But 49 out of 59 isn't bad.

commentBody:
@Times Rita
Do you know something we don't?
@Jacqui J - I finally got to Kansas in 2010, making it my 50th state.
@Captain Quahog that‚Äôs awesome. I hope to be in your league someday
@Times Rita you aren‚Äôt too far from there. You might make it!!

@SBK
LOL. I always proofread before I post anything, anywhere. Unfortunately, my vision is deteriorating faster than ever.

@Zach Not my area of expertise, so: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_(character) ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Happy to learn why it's inaccurate in case it comes up while watching Jeopardy!.üòâ Nevertheless, these are just "clues" rather than definitions.

@SP

In fact, the clue didn't mention Frankenstein at all, in any of its incarnations.  It just said "fictional."
@Zach It definitely was in Mel Brook‚Äôs ‚ÄúYoung Frankenstein,‚Äù portrayed by the fabulous Marty Feldman. A classic.

@SP
What hump?

userLocation: Spring training again. Ahh, at last! ‚öæÔ∏è
commentBody:
@Katie
Ygor had a shofar?!? I'm assuming that this is autocorrect at work but I can't think what from.
@Mike Please supply puns more suitable for the mass market.

Mike,

No, you heft to decide.

So Mike, I hear you‚Äôre going to appear in a video to reveal which is correct, the pound or the kilogram.

I can hardly wait to see unit.

@Mike
An ounce of fine puns is worth a ton of jokes, but we'll have to weight and see if that's going to hold up.

@Barry Ancona,

I finished that puzzle in 1:29:06. Has to be my worst time ever for a Thursday.

@NYC Traveler
I just did a quick stab at just the Across clues, only because, unlike most of you, I still have to go to bed. Wasn't able to fill in a single answer. Later, I'll read Wordplay and see if that helps. I had to have done this puzzle way back then, unless I was on a cruise that didn't offer the daily puzzle. But it's a beast!

@Barry Ancona

I just tried to solve that puzzle.

For the first time ever, I had literally nothing in the grid after my across and down pass ü§™

I had vague ideas as to what two of the entries might be but I wasn't sure enough about either to type them in ü§£

So I guess that's that.

The X-Phile,
As you might imagine given the difficulty of the puzzle, quite a few of those posts were from people whose names we didn't recognize! Some of the others are no longer posting, are no longer posting regularly, or, alas, are no longer. Steve did subsequently clarify his last name initial (which, in lower case in this font, cannot be distinguished from capital I).

@Barry Ancona

I am on 2016 in the archives so just finished it recently. Took me 59 minutes a very long Thursday for me too. I might have even called it out in these comments after I did it as an example of a puzzle that would never fly today in terms of difficulty. But it was friggin‚Äô brilliant especially the clueing of the revealers. I can see how like Pete Rose, Ian may have been banned from the sport after that.

@Wayne Harrison

Yes, indeed.  I was quite confident that it was a gimme.

@Wayne Harrison  I immediately and proudly filled it in.  My grandmother and I used to read it together on Sunday mornings in what she called "the funny papers".  Reluctantly, I deleted it on the first cross.

@Kevin

I don't think you do.
@Kevin Yup!

@Kevin
I had comp for the longest time.

@Andrzej

Next time, just come to Minnesota! It's all you need!! ü©µ‚ù§Ô∏èüíô
@Andrzej Just to confuse matters a little more, in English we have appropriated the word all√©e (or sometimes just allee) for just the kind of thoroughfare you're describing.

@Andrzej

I hope they are able to clone the dodo, and it comes back and teaches us how to integrate general relativity and quantum mechanics.

commentBody:
@Petrol

Isn't it fascinating how cranes have seeded so many words?

"Gruel" is so named because apparently the French among our ancestors made their cheap stew out of crane droppings.

Similarly, gruyere cheese was originally made not with Renner but crane urine. The industrial process has changed over the years, but the name remains.

"Cranberry" has a similar etymology, albeit without the French connection - the fruit looks and tastes like crane poop.

Then there's "cranium" - cranes are more vicious than we give them credit for today. Those beaks can do some damage! Death by crane was a major contributor to mortality rates in 18th century English Lake District. Many people believed the main reason they had thick skulls was to protect them from having their brains devoured by bloodthirsty avians - thus they called a skull a cranium (-um being an early-modern English suffix denoting a protective layer, as also exemplified by scrot-um).
Poc on thee, autocorrect! Renner was supposed to be "rennet".

@Andrzej

You know, I'm not sure how much to believe you any more. 

"Cheap stew out of crane droppings"???

I had stew for dinner and now I'm feeling like I'm going to lose it.

commentBody:
@NYC Traveler
I had the WIZARD, and only needed the ID, but it's a familiar coincidence when there are two possibilities that have the same number of letters, and maddening if I like mine better.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ

To see how it would feel I did a Tuesday puzzle from 1996 today. The fill included some journalist born in the 1800s, some other people I've never heard of, and several unusual words I haven't encountered or at least remembered in my 40 years of learning English. Other than that it felt roughtly like a modern Tuesday. But a sample of one is what it is...

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ

I have argued here that comparing current puzzles with those from the archive introduces a context factor in comparing difficulty.

I submit that taking a puzzle out of its time does change the odds that 1)one is going to not remember an answer for a word or person whose importance peaked around the time of the puzzle's publication, OR, 2)is going to use an answer that didn't exist at the that time.

I trust that the long timers here, and believe there has been an easing of the puzzles. 

But I don't think that can be proven by comparison with the archives, nor can we quantitate how much easier they've become.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ

My experience working thru the archives is that the older (early 
'90s) puzzles are definitely, unequivocally, unarguably more difficult.

And the cultural references work both ways, can help or hinder.

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
@Francis

Not all obvious things require quantitative demonstration in order to be true.

I know, for example, that my memory and reflexes were much better twenty years ago.  There is no way to logically or empirically demonstrate this.

I also know that not only the fill of puzzles years ago was more abstruse but that the clueing was more fiendish, as well.
I wish we did... The church is finally losing its influence over government but it will still be decades before we adopt modern European standards in that respect.

commentBody:
@Jerry
Given the vigorous subversion, er... conversion of numerous elements of English into code words relating to sexuality, one could read the Gettysburg Address and find a subtext. After all, the first noun is 'score'.
@Jerry @Wayno came here to say this very thing. Put in "COMP" then realized "MAD DASHES" needed an "a" and thought "I really hope they haven't used "vamp" to mean improvise. that's just...wrong."

SBK
You reference a very sobering document and I see your point. I think your point is... there are people (like me), who choose to read into just about anything and interpret a non-existent meaning. That's my creative interpretation, albeit not always welcome. It's what I do. More on that in a sec...

Having just visited the battle site, Lincoln was overwhelmed by the aftermath of a horrific and decisive conflict, out of which he had to try and make sense. Then, he had to convey to the American people that something needed to be done and to never let things go so badly again.
Our Declaration of Independence carries equal weight as a plea for some semblance of sanity in an oppressive time.

Other works, such as Tennyson's Charge of the Light Brigade, FDR's Pearl Harbor speech, the D-Day invasion, Churchill's words of comfort to the English, the account of the Battle of Ia Drang, and others, serve as chilling reminders of man's inhumanity to man, when all else fails.

Maybe Abe used "conceived," "proposition" and "score" (although that never came to mind) for an ulterior reason, but doubtful. Our esteemed constructors here consistently use subtle little innuendos, (under close scrutiny and coaching by the editing staff) to keep emotions stirred up, while push their agenda. Makes one wonder, huh?

But, leave it to someone like me to find a sect u al undertone and a feeble attempt at humor in a crossword theme. I do appreciate and welcome your comment, nonetheless.üëç

@Wayno thanks.  I don‚Äôt really know from Jazz. But I had first entered ‚Äúscat‚Äù, which I believe is vocal improvisation in jazz. But with the crosses later came around to VAMP (i knew the term was used in jazz, but not the exact meaning). Looking it up later however, I could find no definition that claimed that ‚Äúvamping‚Äù meant improvising - though I guess one could improvise a vamp and then iterate it (which I suppose might satisfy the ‚Äúit‚Äôs a valid clue‚Äù crowd). However, based on your (and other comments) and my inability to find an any definition that claimed ‚Äúvamping‚Äù could mean improvising. I would call this at best a bad clue (especially for a Monday)- unless someone can point me at some common usage examples.

commentBody:
@Jerry
PS To be clear, i doubt that all the "little innuendoes" that people find are the products of deliberate editorial intent. Some may be, some may just be the products of random chance applied to a given chunk of English text. I entirely disbelieve that there is a deliberate scheme to "keep emotions stirred up" and "push their agenda." What I wonder is what else you've dreamed up.

You had me at "gutter stench," so there's really no need to be any clearer.
For some odd reason, I choose to post a comment or so, in one of the most left-leaning and biased news outlets in America. As a life-long conservative, I see what I see through a conservative-leaning lens, just as you and most of the commenters here see things through a liberal-leaning lens. You have a certain disdain for America, and the current administration, and such is your prerogative. I don't like it at all, but you have your reasons, and I've learned to be ok with it. How a Canadian can target America as negatively as you do, and not other countries, is mystifying to me. I'm not fully on board with the leadership of this country that I fought for and love, but I choose to keep it under wraps. I choose not to criticize the previous administration, but scratch my head at the constant negativity towards America. I have just as little use for conservative news outlets as I do this one.

Again, as a right-leaning conservative, on a liberal board, it just appears  that way to me
If you want to run me off this board and have it all to yourself, then you're no better than the administration you so abhor. If your intent is to have a conversation, this is my reply. If your intent is to try and dress me down, and expose me for the fraud that I am, then let's just call a truce, and not get poor Wayne's comment deleted and move forward.

jacob,

(1) No spoiler alerts needed. The assumption is that everyone has either solved the day's crossword (and mini) or is looking for answers. Just don't comment on other games.
(2) Scroll down for discussions of VAMP (which take place every time it is clued this way).
(3) Finding one "uncommon" word in a Monday puzzle is not uncommon. It is, after all, a crossword.
Soon you can enjoy the Tuesday puzzle.
